snippet: The federal board, which sharply criticized the collection of the phone records of Americans by the N.S.A., has come to a starkly different conclusion about a program monitoring foreigners.
abstract: Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board that sharply criticized the collection of the phone records of Americans by National Security Agency comes to starkly different conclusion about agency’s exploitation of Internet connections in United States to monitor foreigners communicating with one another abroad; holds program is largely in compliance with both Constitution and surveillance law Congress passed six years ago.
lead_paragraph: The federal board, which sharply criticized the collection of the phone records of Americans by the N.S.A., has come to a starkly different conclusion about a program monitoring foreigners.

headline.main: U.S. Privacy Panel Backs N.S.A.’s Internet Tapping
headline.print_headline: U.S. Privacy Panel Backs N.S.A.’s Internet Tapping

keywords.value: Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board
